title: ARP Spoofing Detection
description:
Review this ARP table from a network capture:

? (192.168.1.1) at aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:01 on eth0
? (192.168.1.1) at aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:99 on eth0
? (192.168.1.50) at aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:50 on eth0
? (192.168.1.100) at aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:99 on eth0

Notice that two different IPs share the same MAC address (aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:99). This indicates an ARP spoofing attack.

Which IP is the attacker impersonating (the gateway)?

Submit as: flag{ip_address}
hints: In ARP spoofing, the attacker sends fake ARP replies to associate their MAC with another IP
MAC aa:bb:cc:dd:ee:99 is claimed by both 192.168.1.1 and 192.168.1.100
The attacker (192.168.1.100) is impersonating the gateway (192.168.1.1) to intercept traffic
